contentheadline.headline: The New Adventures of Sherlock Holmes

contentrichtext.text: '''''The New Adventures of Sherlock Holmes''''' was an [[old-time radio]] show which aired in the [[United States of America|USA]] from October 2, 1939 to July 7, 1947. Most episodes were written by the team of Dennis Green and [[Anthony Boucher]]. Originally, the show starred [[Basil Rathbone]] as [[Sherlock Holmes]] and [[Nigel Bruce]] as [[Doctor Watson]]. Together, they starred in 220 episodes which aired weekly on Mondays from 8:30 to 9:00pm. [[Bromo Quinine]] sponsored some of the earlier programs on the NBC Blue Network and for a period Parker Pen was the sponsor. The show first aired on the [[Blue Network]] but later moved to the [[Mutual Broadcasting System]]. It was originally broadcast from Hollywood. During [[World War II]], the show was also broadcast overseas through the [[Old-time_radio#Armed_Forces_Radio_Service|Armed Forces Radio Service]]. It is unknown exactly how many of the original 220 shows have survived, 53 are currently known to be in circulation. Basil Rathbone's last episode as the famous Detective was "The Singular Affair of the Baconian Cipher." He was eager to separate himself from the show to avoid being typecast as Sherlock Holmes, and even though the show's sponsor [[Petri Wine]] offered him generous pay to continue, he decided to move on. Once he did, the sponsor did as well, and [[Tom Conway]] took the starring role, though Nigel Bruce got top billing and was always announced first. The new sponsor was [[Kreml Hair Tonic for Men]], and the new series lasted only 39 episodes. Tom Conway was replaced midseason by John Stanley. The show was later sponsored by [[Clipper Craft]] menswear and broadcast from New York City. With Rathbone and Bruce, the show exhibited an interesting introduction. The sponsor's spokesman, usually [[Harry Bartell]], or, during the show's initial season and again in the final season, Joseph Bell, would show up weekly at Dr. Watson's house (then retired and living in [[California]]), and share a story about Holmes and his adventures over a glass of Petri wine. This offered them the chance to sometimes bring in other characters to contribute to the story, and also gave Watson a chance to summarize or add additional titbits at the end. Another interesting thing about this radio show's introductions was Dr. Watson's anecdotes and comments about his [[dogs]] usually referred to as the "Puppies." ==External links== *[http://www.otrsite.com/logs/logs1041.htm Jerry Haendiges Vintage Radio Logs: ''The New Adventures of Sherlock Holmes''] *[http://colsearch.nfsa.afc.gov.au/nfsa/search/display/display.w3p;adv=yes;group=;groupequals=;holdingType=;page=0;parentid=;query=Number%3A646103%20Category%3A%22RADIO%20DRAMA%20SERIES%2FSERIAL%22;querytype=;rec=0;resCount=10 Sherlock Holmes at the Australian National Film and Sound Archive] *[http://www.rathboneandbruce.net/the-new-adventures-of-sherlock-holmes.html A Tribute to Basil Rathbone and Nigel Bruce: ''The New Adventures of Sherlock Holmes''] *[http://www.botar.us/sherlockholmes.html ''Botar's Old Time Radio'' (free mp3 downloads)] *[http://sherlock.mindcop.net/index.html ''Sherlock Holmes Public Library'' (Most of the programs plus lots of other Sherlockiana)] *[http://www.archive.org/search.php?query=sherlock%20holmes ''Sherlock Holmes programs available on the Internet Archive.Org''] {{DEFAULTSORT:New Adventures of Sherlock Holmes, The}} [[Category:American radio drama]] [[Category:1930s American radio programs]] [[Category:1940s American radio programs]] [[Category:Works based on Sherlock Holmes]] {{US-radio-show-stub}}
